name: NAD⁺ Precursors
summary: NAD⁺ precursors such as nicotinamide riboside (NR), nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN), and niacinamide are supplements that aim to increase cellular NAD⁺ levels, supporting energy metabolism, mitochondrial function, and healthy aging.
description: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD⁺) is a coenzyme essential for energy production, DNA repair, and cellular signaling. NAD⁺ levels decline with age and stress, which has been linked to fatigue, metabolic dysfunction, neurodegeneration, and mood disorders. Supplementing with NAD⁺ precursors such as nicotinamide riboside (NR), nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN), niacinamide, or niacin may help restore NAD⁺ availability. Preclinical studies suggest benefits for mitochondrial health, resilience to stress, and neuroprotection, though large-scale human psychiatric trials remain limited.

metadata.natural_source: Meat, fish, milk, whole grains, vegetables (trace amounts of NR/NMN)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

off_label_uses: Potential use in mood disorders and stress resilience
contraindications: Active liver disease (high doses of niacinamide/niacin)
Hypotension (with high-dose niacin due to flushing)
monitoring_required: Blood glucose (niacin may worsen insulin resistance at high doses)

items: Promotes cellular repair and longevity pathways
May improve resilience to stress and fatigue
Explored for neuroprotection and mood regulation

sections.text: NAD⁺ precursors restore intracellular NAD⁺ levels, which are essential for ATP production, DNA repair, and regulation of sirtuins and PARPs. By enhancing NAD⁺ availability, these compounds support mitochondrial function, stress adaptation, and potentially neuroprotective processes.

adult.typical: NR or NMN: 250–500 mg/day; Niacinamide: 250–1000 mg/day; Niacin: 100–500 mg/day (extended-release options available)
adult.note: Doses vary by compound. High doses of niacin can cause flushing and liver enzyme elevations.

sections.text: NAD⁺ levels may rise within hours to days of supplementation. Clinical benefits for energy and resilience may require weeks of use.

serious: Liver enzyme elevations at high doses
Insulin resistance with long-term high-dose niacin

other: High-dose niacin requires monitoring for liver toxicity.
May worsen insulin resistance in susceptible individuals.
Use cautiously in those with active cancer, as NAD⁺ may theoretically support tumor metabolism (preclinical).

items.risk: Niacin may increase risk of muscle toxicity when combined

sections.pregnancy: Insufficient safety data; avoid unless prescribed
sections.geriatrics: Often targeted for healthy aging; monitor liver function if using niacin

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: Nicotinamide riboside (NR) and nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN) are newer, more bioavailable NAD⁺ precursors compared to niacinamide or niacin.
Human psychiatric and cognitive studies remain preliminary, though some trials suggest benefits in fatigue and cognitive aging.
Popular in longevity and biohacking communities.
